title: Abel-Ruffini Theorem
description: Galois's profound theorem that there is no general algebraic solution to polynomial equations of degree five or higher, connecting field theory to group theory through the unsolvability of the symmetric group S5.

title: Arithmetic Mean - Geometric Mean Inequality
description: The AM-GM Inequality: For non-negative real numbers, the arithmetic mean is always greater than or equal to the geometric mean, with equality if and only if all numbers are equal.

title: Impossibility of Trisecting an Angle
description: The classical impossibility proof that an arbitrary angle cannot be trisected using only compass and straightedge, along with the impossibility of doubling the cube. These problems puzzled mathematicians for over 2000 years until Wantzel's 1837 proof.

title: Area of a Circle
description: The area of a circle with radius r is πr². One of the most fundamental formulas in geometry, known since Archimedes proved it around 250 BCE.

title: Sum of an Arithmetic Series
description: Gauss's formula for the sum of the first n natural numbers: 1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2. A classic result with a famous anecdote about young Gauss.

title: The Ballot Problem
description: In an election where candidate A receives p votes and candidate B receives q votes (p > q), the probability that A leads throughout the counting is (p-q)/(p+q).

title: The Basel Problem: Sum of Reciprocal Squares
description: The sum of reciprocals of squares equals π²/6. Euler's famous 1734 solution to the Basel Problem launched his illustrious career.

title: Bertrand's Postulate
description: For every integer n > 1, there exists a prime p such that n < p ≤ 2n. Conjectured by Bertrand (1845), first proved by Chebyshev (1852), with an elegant elementary proof by Erdős (1932).

title: Bezout's Identity
description: For any integers a, b, there exist x, y such that ax + by = gcd(a,b). Fundamental to number theory.

title: The Binomial Theorem
description: (x + y)^n = Σ C(n,k) x^k y^(n-k). One of the most fundamental results in algebra and combinatorics.

title: Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. The rank of an elliptic curve equals the order of vanishing of its L-function at s=1.

title: The Birthday Problem
description: The surprising probability that in a group of just 23 people, there's a greater than 50% chance that two share a birthday. A classic example of how probability defies intuition.

title: Borsuk-Ulam Theorem
description: For any continuous function from the n-sphere to n-dimensional Euclidean space, there exist antipodal points with the same image. The 'weather theorem' that guarantees antipodal points on Earth with identical temperature and pressure.

title: Brouwer Fixed Point Theorem
description: Every continuous function from a closed ball to itself has at least one fixed point. A cornerstone of topology with profound applications in economics, game theory, and differential equations.

title: Buffon's Needle Problem
description: If a needle of length l is dropped onto a floor with parallel lines spaced distance d apart, the probability it crosses a line is 2l/(pi*d).

title: Cantor's Diagonalization Theorem
description: Cantor's elegant 1891 proof that the real numbers are uncountable, using the famous diagonal argument to show no enumeration can list all infinite binary sequences.

title: Cantor's Theorem
description: For any set A, there is no surjection from A to its power set P(A). This establishes that |A| < |P(A)| = 2^|A|, proving the hierarchy of infinite cardinalities.

title: Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality
description: |⟨u,v⟩| ≤ ‖u‖·‖v‖. Fundamental to functional analysis and quantum mechanics.

title: Cayley-Hamilton Theorem
description: Every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial. If A is an n×n matrix with characteristic polynomial p(λ) = det(λI - A), then p(A) = 0.

title: Central Limit Theorem
description: The sum of a large number of independent random variables converges to a normal distribution. This proof combines the classical characteristic function approach with an algebraic topological interpretation of the Gaussian as an attractor.

title: Ceva's Theorem
description: Ceva's Theorem (Wiedijk's #61): Given a triangle ABC with cevians AD, BE, CF, these lines are concurrent if and only if (AF/FB) * (BD/DC) * (CE/EA) = 1

title: Chinese Remainder Theorem (Constructive)
description: For pairwise coprime moduli, there exists a unique solution to any system of congruences. Includes the classic Sunzi problem: find n where n = 2 (mod 3), n = 3 (mod 5), n = 2 (mod 7). Answer: 23.

title: Collatz Conjecture for Structured Values
description: The Collatz sequence reaches 1 for powers of 2 and numbers of the form 2^k * m where m reaches 1. Verified cases include 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, and 27 (which takes 111 steps).

title: Formula for the Number of Combinations
description: The number of ways to choose k elements from a set of n elements is C(n,k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!). This fundamental formula in combinatorics counts the number of k-element subsets of an n-element set.

title: Independence of the Continuum Hypothesis
description: The Continuum Hypothesis is independent of ZFC set theory. Godel showed CH is consistent with ZFC; Cohen showed not-CH is also consistent.

title: Cramer's Rule
description: For Ax = b with det(A) ≠ 0, xᵢ = det(Aᵢ)/det(A) where Aᵢ has column i replaced by b.

title: De Moivre's Theorem
description: (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ). Connects powers of complex numbers to multiple angle formulas.

title: Denumerability of the Rationals
description: Cantor's proof that the rational numbers are countable: despite being dense in the reals, there exists a bijection between the natural numbers and the rationals.

title: The Derangements Formula
description: The number of permutations with no fixed points: D(n) = n! Σ(-1)^k/k!. The 'hat-check problem'.

title: Desargues's Theorem
description: Desargues's Theorem (Wiedijk's #87): If two triangles are in perspective from a point, then they are in perspective from a line, and conversely.

title: Descartes' Rule of Signs
description: The number of positive real roots of a polynomial is either equal to the number of sign changes in the coefficient sequence, or less than it by an even number.

title: Dirichlet's Theorem on Primes in Arithmetic Progressions
description: For any two positive coprime integers a and q, there are infinitely many primes congruent to a modulo q. This foundational result in analytic number theory uses Dirichlet characters and L-functions.

title: Dissection of Cubes
description: A cube cannot be dissected into a finite number of smaller cubes, all of different sizes.

title: Divisibility by 3 Rule
description: A natural number is divisible by 3 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 3. This ancient divisibility test works because 10 ≡ 1 (mod 3).

title: Transcendence of e
description: The number e = 2.71828... is transcendental: it is not a root of any polynomial with integer coefficients. The first number proven transcendental by Hermite.

title: Erdős Problem #1: Distinct Subset Sums
description: If A is a subset of {1,...,N} with n elements and all 2^n subset sums are distinct, then N >> 2^n. Erdős's 'first serious problem' (1931). OPEN with $500 prize.

title: Erdős–Szekeres Theorem
description: Any sequence of at least (r-1)(s-1) + 1 distinct numbers contains either an increasing subsequence of length r, or a decreasing subsequence of length s.

title: Euler's Identity
description: The most beautiful equation in mathematics: e^(iπ) + 1 = 0. This elegant identity connects five fundamental constants—e, i, π, 1, and 0—in one perfect equation.

title: Euler's Polyhedral Formula
description: For any convex polyhedron: V - E + F = 2, where V = vertices, E = edges, F = faces. This is the Euler characteristic of a sphere.

title: Euler's Generalization of Fermat's Little Theorem
description: For coprime integers a and n, a^φ(n) ≡ 1 (mod n), where φ(n) is Euler's totient function. This generalizes Fermat's Little Theorem.

title: Factor and Remainder Theorems
description: Two fundamental theorems connecting polynomial division, roots, and evaluation: (x - a) divides p(x) iff p(a) = 0 (Factor Theorem), and the remainder when dividing p(x) by (x - a) equals p(a) (Remainder Theorem).

title: The Fair Games Theorem
description: In a fair game (expected gain is zero), a gambler with finite wealth playing against an infinitely wealthy opponent will eventually go bankrupt with probability 1.

title: Fermat's Sum of Two Squares
description: A prime p can be expressed as a sum of two squares if and only if p = 2 or p is congruent to 1 (mod 4). Formalized using Zagier's elegant one-sentence proof.

title: Fermat's Last Theorem
description: Andrew Wiles' monumental proof that there are no three positive integers a, b, c such that a^n + b^n = c^n for any integer n > 2, resolving a 358-year-old conjecture through the modularity of elliptic curves.

title: Feuerbach's Theorem
description: The nine-point circle of a triangle is tangent to its incircle and all three excircles. A beautiful result in triangle geometry.

title: Four Color Theorem
description: Every planar map can be colored with at most four colors such that no adjacent regions share a color. First major theorem proved by computer (1976), the proof sparked debates about the nature of mathematical truth.

title: Fourier Series
description: Every periodic function can be represented as an infinite sum of sines and cosines (Fourier series). A cornerstone of analysis with applications throughout science.

title: Friendship Theorem
description: The Friendship Theorem (Erdős–Rényi–Sós, 1966): In any finite graph where every pair of distinct vertices has exactly one common neighbor, there exists a 'politician' vertex adjacent to all others.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
description: Every integer > 1 is uniquely representable as a product of primes. The cornerstone of number theory.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
description: Every non-constant polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root. This profound theorem reveals that the complex numbers are algebraically closed - they contain all solutions to polynomial equations.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
description: The profound connection between differentiation and integration: Newton and Leibniz's crowning achievement that unified the two pillars of calculus into a single coherent theory.

title: Greatest Common Divisor Algorithm
description: The Euclidean algorithm correctly computes the GCD: gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, a mod b). One of the oldest algorithms still in use, dating back to Euclid's Elements (c. 300 BCE).

title: Gelfond-Schneider Theorem
description: If a and b are algebraic numbers with a not equal to 0, 1 and b irrational, then a^b is transcendental. Resolves Hilbert's 7th Problem.

title: Solution of the General Quartic
description: Ferrari's method for solving quartic equations using a resolvent cubic. Every quartic x^4 + ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d = 0 can be solved by radicals.

title: Sum of a Geometric Series
description: The classic formulas for finite and infinite geometric series: for |r| < 1, the infinite sum converges to 1/(1-r).

title: Gödel's First Incompleteness Theorem
description: Any consistent formal system capable of expressing basic arithmetic contains statements that are true but unprovable within the system. This 1931 theorem shattered Hilbert's program and revealed fundamental limits of formal reasoning.

title: Green's Theorem
description: Green's theorem relates a line integral around a closed curve to a double integral over the enclosed region, connecting circulation to curl.

title: Undecidability of the Halting Problem
description: Turing's 1936 proof that no algorithm can determine whether an arbitrary program halts, establishing fundamental limits on computation using the diagonal argument.

title: Divergence of the Harmonic Series
description: The harmonic series 1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + ... diverges, despite its terms approaching zero. A classic result with an elegant 14th-century proof.

title: The Hermite-Lindemann Theorem
description: For any non-zero algebraic number alpha, e^alpha is transcendental. This implies the transcendence of both e and pi.

title: Heron's Formula
description: Area = √(s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)) where s is the semi-perimeter. Computes triangle area from side lengths alone.

title: Hilbert's Tenth Problem: Undecidability of Diophantine Equations
description: The MRDP theorem (1970) proves that no algorithm can determine whether an arbitrary Diophantine equation has integer solutions, answering Hilbert's 1900 challenge in the negative.

title: Hilbert's 11th Problem: Quadratic Forms
description: Classification of quadratic forms over number fields. The Hasse-Minkowski theorem provides a local-global principle for rational solutions.

title: Hilbert's 13th Problem: Superposition of Functions
description: The Kolmogorov-Arnold theorem (1956-57) disproves Hilbert's conjecture: every continuous function of n variables can be represented using functions of only one variable.

title: Hilbert's Fourteenth Problem: Finiteness of Invariant Systems
description: Hilbert's 14th problem asked whether the ring of invariants is always finitely generated. Nagata (1959) showed the answer is NO in general, but Hilbert-Mumford proved YES for reductive groups.

title: Hilbert's 15th Problem: Schubert Calculus
description: Rigorous foundation of Schubert's enumerative calculus for counting geometric configurations in Grassmannians.

title: Hilbert's 16th Problem: Limit Cycles
description: The maximum number of limit cycles for polynomial vector fields remains one of the most notorious open problems in mathematics.

title: Hilbert's 17th Problem: Sum of Squares
description: Artin's theorem: every non-negative polynomial is a sum of squares of rational functions, but not necessarily polynomials (Motzkin's counterexample).

title: Hilbert's Nineteenth Problem: Regularity of Variational Solutions
description: Hilbert's 1900 question on whether variational minimizers are analytic was resolved affirmatively by De Giorgi (1957) and Nash (1958): solutions of uniformly elliptic PDEs with smooth data are smooth.

title: Hilbert's Twentieth Problem: Boundary Value Problems
description: Hilbert's 1900 question about the solvability of boundary value problems was resolved through Lax-Milgram (1954) for elliptic PDEs, but Lewy's example (1957) showed some smooth PDEs have no solutions.

title: Hilbert's 21st Problem: Riemann-Hilbert Problem
description: The Riemann-Hilbert problem asks whether a Fuchsian system exists with given singularities and monodromy. The answer is YES for irreducible representations (Plemelj, 1908), but NO in general (Bolibrukh, 1989).

title: Hilbert's Twenty-Second Problem: Uniformization Theorem
description: The Uniformization Theorem (Koebe-Poincare, 1907) proves that every simply connected Riemann surface is conformally equivalent to the Riemann sphere, the complex plane, or the unit disk, completely solving Hilbert's call for uniformization by automorphic functions.

title: Hilbert's Twenty-Third Problem: Calculus of Variations
description: Hilbert's 1900 call for further development of the calculus of variations has been spectacularly answered through direct methods (Tonelli), weak solutions (Sobolev), optimal control (Pontryagin), and geometric measure theory.

title: Hilbert's 3rd Problem: Scissors Congruence
description: The Dehn invariant proves that a cube and regular tetrahedron of equal volume are NOT scissors congruent, answering Hilbert's 3rd Problem.

title: Hilbert's 4th Problem: Straight Line as Shortest Distance
description: Busemann's characterization of projective metrics where straight lines are geodesics, including Minkowski and Hilbert geometries.

title: Hilbert's 5th Problem: Lie Groups Without Differentiability
description: Are continuous groups automatically differential groups? The Montgomery-Zippin theorem (1952) shows that locally Euclidean topological groups are Lie groups.

title: Hilbert's Sixth Problem: Axiomatization of Physics
description: Hilbert's 1900 call for rigorous axiomatization of physics has been partially achieved through Kolmogorov's probability axioms (1933), von Neumann's quantum mechanics (1932), and other foundational frameworks.

title: Hilbert's Ninth Problem: The Most General Reciprocity Law
description: Hilbert's 9th problem asked for the most general reciprocity law in algebraic number fields. The answer is Artin reciprocity (1927), which unifies quadratic, cubic, and all higher reciprocity laws through class field theory.

title: The Hodge Conjecture
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Every Hodge class on a projective variety is a rational combination of algebraic cycle classes.

title: Hurwitz's Theorem
description: There are only four n-square identities: for n = 1, 2, 4, 8. This profound constraint explains why only the reals, complex numbers, quaternions, and octonions can be normed division algebras. Includes a complete proof that n=3 is impossible.

title: Principle of Inclusion/Exclusion
description: The fundamental counting principle for unions of finite sets: |A ∪ B| = |A| + |B| - |A ∩ B|, and its generalization to three or more sets.

title: Infinitude of Prime Numbers
description: Euclid's elegant proof that there are infinitely many prime numbers, formalized in Lean 4 with Mathlib.

title: Intermediate Value Theorem
description: A continuous function on a closed interval attains every value between its endpoints: the foundational theorem connecting topology to analysis.

title: The Isoperimetric Theorem
description: Among all curves of a given perimeter, the circle encloses the maximum area. Equivalently, among all shapes of a given area, the circle has minimum perimeter.

title: Isosceles Triangle Theorem
description: In an isosceles triangle, the base angles are equal. Known as Pons Asinorum (Bridge of Asses).

title: Kepler Conjecture: Sphere Packing
description: The face-centered cubic lattice achieves the maximum sphere packing density of pi/(3*sqrt(2)). Part of Hilbert's 18th Problem, proven by Hales (1998).

title: Knight's Tour Oblique Angles
description: Every closed knight's tour has at least 4 oblique (>90 degree) turns, and exactly one tour achieves this minimum. Based on Donald Knuth's 2025 Christmas Lecture.

title: Königsberg Bridges Problem
description: Euler's 1736 proof that it's impossible to walk through Königsberg crossing each of its seven bridges exactly once. This problem founded graph theory.

title: Kronecker's Jugendtraum (Hilbert's 12th)
description: Hilbert's 12th Problem asks to extend the Kronecker-Weber theorem: find explicit generators for all abelian extensions of number fields.

title: Kummer's Theorem on Binomial Coefficients
description: The p-adic valuation of C(n,k) equals the number of carries when adding k and n-k in base p. A beautiful connection between combinatorics and positional numeral systems.

title: Lagrange's Four Squares Theorem
description: Every natural number can be expressed as the sum of four squares, a profound result connecting number theory to quaternion algebra.

title: Lagrange's Theorem
description: For a finite group G and subgroup H, the order of H divides the order of G. Fundamental to group theory.

title: Law of Cosines
description: The generalization of the Pythagorean theorem to arbitrary triangles: c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab*cos(C), which reduces to the Pythagorean theorem when C = 90 degrees.

title: Laws of Large Numbers
description: The Laws of Large Numbers describe how sample averages converge to expected values. The Weak Law shows convergence in probability, while the Strong Law shows almost sure convergence.

title: Lebesgue Measure
description: Lebesgue measure extends the notion of length/area/volume to a rich class of sets, enabling the powerful Lebesgue integral that revolutionized analysis.

title: Legendre's Conjecture (Partial)
description: Legendre's conjecture states there's always a prime between n^2 and (n+1)^2. Verified with explicit witnesses for n = 1 to 20.

title: Leibniz's Series for Pi
description: The Leibniz formula for pi: the alternating series 1 - 1/3 + 1/5 - 1/7 + ... converges to pi/4.

title: L'Hopital's Rule
description: A fundamental technique for evaluating limits of indeterminate forms: if f(x)/g(x) approaches 0/0 or infinity/infinity, then the limit equals the limit of f'(x)/g'(x).

title: Liouville's Theorem on Transcendental Numbers
description: Liouville numbers are transcendental. This provides the first explicit construction of transcendental numbers via rational approximation bounds.

title: The Principle of Mathematical Induction
description: For any predicate P on natural numbers, if P(0) holds and P(n) implies P(n+1) for all n, then P(n) holds for all n. Peano's fifth axiom and the foundation of recursive proofs.

title: Mean Value Theorem
description: If f is continuous on [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b), there exists c where f'(c) = (f(b)-f(a))/(b-a).

title: Minkowski's Fundamental Theorem
description: A convex, centrally symmetric body with volume greater than 2^n contains a non-zero lattice point. Foundational for the geometry of numbers.

title: Morley's Theorem
description: The three angle trisectors of any triangle, taken in pairs, meet to form an equilateral triangle. A surprising result discovered in 1899.

title: Motivic Class of Genus 0 Maps to Flag Varieties
description: The motivic class of based rational maps from P¹ to flag varieties equals the class of GL_n times affine space in the Grothendieck ring of varieties.

title: Global Regularity for Navier-Stokes
description: A conditional regularity theorem for the Navier-Stokes Millennium Prize Problem. We identify the precise structural obstruction (scale-bridging concentration) and formulate the minimal Bubble Persistence hypothesis B′ under which all known tools close: B′ → Type I → ESŠ → regularity.

title: P vs NP Problem
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Can every problem whose solution can be verified quickly also be solved quickly?

title: Independence of the Parallel Postulate
description: Euclid's parallel postulate is independent of the other axioms of geometry. There exist consistent geometries (Euclidean and hyperbolic) that differ on this postulate.

title: Euler's Partition Theorem
description: The number of partitions of n into odd parts equals the number of partitions into distinct parts. A beautiful bijection in combinatorics.

title: Pascal's Hexagon Theorem
description: If a hexagon is inscribed in a conic section, the three pairs of opposite sides meet at collinear points. A fundamental result in projective geometry.

title: Solutions to Pell's Equation
description: Pell's equation x^2 - Dy^2 = 1 always has infinitely many solutions when D is not a perfect square, all generated from a unique fundamental solution.

title: Perfect Number Theorem
description: The Euclid-Euler theorem: a number is even and perfect if and only if it has the form 2^(p-1)(2^p - 1) where 2^p - 1 is a Mersenne prime.

title: Transcendence of Pi
description: Pi is transcendental: it is not a root of any polynomial with integer coefficients. This proves the impossibility of squaring the circle with ruler and compass.

title: Pick's Theorem
description: The area of a simple lattice polygon equals I + B/2 - 1, where I is the number of interior lattice points and B is the number of boundary lattice points.

title: The Number of Platonic Solids
description: There are exactly five Platonic solids (regular convex polyhedra): the tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron.

title: The Poincare Conjecture
description: Every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to the 3-sphere. Solved by Grigori Perelman in 2002-2003 using Ricci flow with surgery.

title: The Prime Number Theorem
description: The prime counting function pi(x) is asymptotically equivalent to x/ln(x). This describes the distribution of prime numbers among positive integers.

title: Divergence of Prime Reciprocals
description: The sum of reciprocals of all prime numbers diverges: 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7 + 1/11 + ... = infinity.

title: Primitive Roots Modulo Primes
description: For any prime p, there are exactly φ(p-1) primitive roots modulo p. Uses the cyclic structure of (ℤ/pℤ)* and Mathlib's counting theorem.

title: Product of Segments of Chords
description: If two chords of a circle intersect at point P, then the product of the segments of one chord equals the product of the segments of the other: PA * PB = PC * PD.

title: Ptolemy's Theorem
description: For a cyclic quadrilateral, the product of diagonals equals the sum of products of opposite sides: AC·BD = AB·CD + BC·DA

title: Puiseux's Theorem
description: The field of Puiseux series (fractional power series) is algebraically closed. This provides a concrete algebraic closure of the Laurent series field.

title: Pythagorean Theorem
description: The most famous theorem in mathematics: in a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides. a² + b² = c²

title: Formula for Pythagorean Triples
description: All primitive Pythagorean triples (a,b,c) with a² + b² = c² are given by a = m² - n², b = 2mn, c = m² + n² for coprime m > n > 0.

title: Law of Quadratic Reciprocity
description: Gauss's 'golden theorem' of number theory: for distinct odd primes p and q, the Legendre symbols (p/q) and (q/p) are equal unless both p and q are congruent to 3 mod 4.

title: The Ramanujan Sum Fallacy
description: A demonstration of how Lean catches the famous fallacious 'proof' that 1+2+3+... = -1/12, showing why mathematical rigor matters.

title: Ramsey's Theorem
description: Frank Ramsey's foundational theorem in combinatorics: for any 2-coloring of the complete graph K_n with sufficiently large n, there exists a monochromatic clique.

title: Randomized MaxCut Approximation
description: A formal proof that a simple randomized algorithm achieves a 1/2-approximation for the NP-Complete Maximum Cut problem, using linearity of expectation.

title: The Riemann Hypothesis
description: A formalization of the Riemann Hypothesis, one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. We state RH precisely using Mathlib's zeta function, prove key equivalences (Robin's inequality, Mertens bound), and document partial results like Hardy's theorem on infinitely many zeros on the critical line.

title: Russell's 1+1=2
description: The legendary proof that 1+1=2, which famously took 362 pages in Principia Mathematica but is trivial in modern type theory.

title: Schroeder-Bernstein Theorem
description: If there exist injections f: A to B and g: B to A, then there exists a bijection between A and B. This establishes that cardinality is antisymmetric.

title: Solution of the Cubic Equation
description: Cardano's formula provides explicit radical solutions to cubic equations. The formula was discovered in the 16th century during the Italian mathematical renaissance.

title: Sophie Germain Primes
description: A prime p is a Sophie Germain prime if 2p+1 is also prime. We prove that all Sophie Germain primes greater than 3 must have the form 6k-1 (equivalently, p ≡ 5 mod 6).

title: Basic Lean Examples
description: A collection of simple example proofs demonstrating basic Lean tactics including non-negativity of squares and implication transitivity.

title: Square Root of 2 is Irrational (From Axioms)
description: A complete proof that sqrt(2) is irrational built from first principles, demonstrating the classical proof by contradiction with even/odd analysis.

title: Irrationality of Square Roots
description: The classic proof that √2 is irrational, generalized to show √n is irrational for any non-perfect-square n. Covers √2, √3, √5, √6, √7 and the general theorem.

title: Stirling's Formula
description: Stirling's approximation for factorials: n! ~ sqrt(2*pi*n) * (n/e)^n. The ratio approaches 1 as n goes to infinity.

title: Number of Subsets of a Set
description: A finite set with n elements has exactly 2^n subsets. This fundamental result connects set theory to binary counting.

title: Sum of kth Powers (Faulhaber's Formulas)
description: Closed-form formulas for sums of consecutive kth powers, including the remarkable identity that the sum of cubes equals the square of the sum.

title: Sylow's Theorems
description: The three Sylow theorems: existence of Sylow p-subgroups, their conjugacy, and counting constraints. Fundamental structure theorems for finite groups.

title: Szemeredi's Theorem (k=3 via Mathlib)
description: Dense subsets of natural numbers contain arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. The k=3 case (Roth's theorem) is fully proved using Mathlib's corners theorem chain.

title: Taylor's Theorem
description: A smooth function can be approximated by its Taylor polynomial, with explicit remainder terms (Lagrange and Cauchy forms).

title: Universality of Three-Place Identity
description: Tom Etter's Universality Theorem: three-place relative identity is foundationally adequate for all of mathematics, establishing mutual interpretability with ZF set theory.

title: Sum of Angles of a Triangle
description: The sum of the interior angles of a triangle equals 180° (π radians). One of the most fundamental results in Euclidean geometry.

title: The Triangle Inequality
description: The fundamental inequality stating that the sum of any two sides of a triangle exceeds the third side. For real numbers: |x + y| ≤ |x| + |y|.

title: Sum of Reciprocals of Triangular Numbers
description: The sum of reciprocals of triangular numbers equals 2: ∑(2/(n(n+1))) = 2. A beautiful telescoping series result.

title: Twin Primes in Special Forms
description: Twin prime pairs (p, p+2) where both are prime must have the form (6k-1, 6k+1) for p > 3. A structural theorem constraining where twin primes can occur.

title: Vieta's Formulas
description: Vieta's formulas relate polynomial coefficients to sums and products of roots. For x^2 - bx + c = 0 with roots r, s: r + s = b and r * s = c.

title: Wilson's Theorem
description: A natural number n > 1 is prime if and only if (n-1)! is congruent to -1 modulo n. A beautiful characterization connecting factorials and primality.

title: Wolstenholme's Theorem
description: For prime p >= 5, the binomial coefficient C(2p-1, p-1) = 1 (mod p^3). Verified computationally for p = 5, 7, 11, 13. Connected to harmonic number divisibility.

title: Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Prove that quantum Yang-Mills theory exists and has a positive mass gap.
